articles.title: Terrifying update on world's largest iceberg now visible from space
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: The world's biggest iceberg has been on the move for the last two years after being stuck to the ocean floor for more than 30 years. Experts are concerned it might fall apart and experts are concerned with it falling apart.   Â   y

articles.title: Shorebird migration book discussion set Sept. 9
articles.summary: Bruce M. Beehler is an ornithologist, naturalist, conservationist, lecturer and author of nature books. He is a research associate in the division of birds at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. His new book, 'Flight of the Godwit: Tracking Epic Shorebird Migrations,' chronicles his journey driving 35,000 miles between 2019 and 2023 in search of North America's largest and farthest-flying shorebirds.

articles.title: New U.S. trade decision impacts Maritime producers
articles.summary: The elimination of the de minimis exemption could be problematic for Maritime producers. Atlantic Watch is concerned about the impact on Maritime producers and their products. The de minimi exemption is a de facto exemption for maritime products. It applies to all products produced within the maritime boundaries.

articles.title: BLM reminds the public to prevent wildfire over Labor Day weekend
articles.author: Wash
articles.summary: The public is urged to prevent human-caused wildfires. The recent high temperatures and continued dry conditions increase the potential for fire starts and rapid spread. About 85% of wildfires are caused by human activities. The widespread heat and prolonged severe drought can cause wildfires to grow very quickly.

articles.title: BLM reminds the public to prevent wildfire over Labor Day weekend
articles.author: Wash
articles.summary: The public is urged to prevent human-caused wildfires. The recent high temperatures and continued dry conditions increase the potential for fire starts and rapid spread. About 85% of wildfires are caused by human activities. The widespread heat and prolonged severe drought can cause wildfires to grow very quickly.

articles.title: Canada's 2023 wildfires fueled air pollution. What could it mean for life expectancy?
articles.author: Mason Goodfellow
articles.summary: Report says Canada's record-breaking 2023 wildfires drove air pollution to its highest levels in decades. There are concerns about the long-term impact on Canadians' health and life expectancy due to climate change. More information on air quality concerns can be found on the Air Quality Life Index website.

articles.title: More than 3.5 million birds migrated over Colorado in 1 night this week. Residents are ...
articles.author: Steamboat Pilot
articles.summary: Millions of birds are flying over Colorado each night during the annual fall migration. People are being asked to dim their lights to aid the migrating birds. Nearly 80% of birds migrate north in the spring and south in the fall, and artificial lights are a big problem for them.

articles.title: Floods devastate Kaghan tourism
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Heavy rains, flash floods, and cloudbursts have severely affected the tourism industry of Kaghan Valley. Tourist flow during July and August remained negligible, leaving popular destinations such as Shogran, Kaghan, Naran, and Babusar Top deserted. Businesses linked to tourism are facing heavy losses.

articles.title: Terrifying update on world's largest iceberg now visible from space
articles.author: Sam Elliott-Gibbs
articles.summary: The world's biggest iceberg, A23a, has been on the move for the last two years after being stuck to the ocean floor for more than 30 years. Antarctica is melting faster than expected and the structure of the iceberg is rapidly weakening. It is moving towards the island of South Georgia, which is home to penguins, seals and sea birds.

articles.title: Tiafoe bounced out in US Open third round
articles.author: Afp Afp
articles.summary: Showers are expected to develop after midnight in Griffin, GA. The weather is going to be cloudy with a high of 66F and a low of 66C. The rain is expected to be heavy and last for a few hours. The risk of flooding is high.

articles.title: Tropicana Field Roof
articles.author: CHO
articles.summary: The roof over Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Florida, was destroyed in 2024 by Hurricane Milton. Workers begin replacing the roof on Friday, Aug. 29, 2025, to replace the roof that was destroyed by Milton in 2024. The roof will be replaced with a new one.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.summary: Parents for Climate wants Australia to set a net zero emissions reduction target by 2035. The group's legal team sent a letter to the Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen two weeks ago. Australia and other countries signed up to the Paris Agreement must produce updated contributions to world temperature goals every five years. The next climate talks are in Brazil in November.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Parents for Climate wants the federal government to set a 2035 climate target. Businesses, including Volvo Group Australia and Fortescue, came out in support of 75 per cent target this week. The International Court of Justice issued an advisory opinion on climate change this year.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Emissions targets have become a fault line for the federal coalition. Some see the pursuit of net zero by 2050 as an act of "economic self-sabotage". Moderates worry backsliding on climate will alienate voters, especially in urban electorates.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: A group of worried parents is turning up the heat on Australia's climate ambition. Parents for Climate members are looking to the legal system to push for rapid emissions cuts. A letter sent by Equity Generation Lawyers, acting on behalf of the activists, specifies net zero by 2035 as the only target consistent with 1.5C and the best available science. Chris Bowen will respond to the letter in due course.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: A group of worried parents is turning up the heat on Australia's climate ambition. They are concerned about the impact of climate change on their children's education.       .   in Australia's education system is not adequately addressing climate change.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Parents for Climate member Kate Smolders wants a 2035 target that assures the best for her children. ACM network's editors and journalists bring you news and views from all over. Get the essential national news digest: all the big issues on Wednesday and great reading every Saturday. Get news, reviews and expert insights every Thursday from CarExpert, ACM's exclusive motoring partner.

articles.title: 'Law on our side': parents push for bold climate target
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Parents for Climate member Kate Smolders wants a 2035 target that assures the best for her children. A group of worried parents is turning up the heat on Australia's climate ambition. Create a free account to read this article or signup to continue reading.

articles.title: More than 3.5 million birds migrated over Colorado in 1 night this week. Residents are being asked to turn out their lights to help them
articles.author: Ryan Spencer
articles.summary: Lights Out Colorado reminds Colorado residents to turn out their lights during the annual fall migration. The peak bird migration starts on Sept. 1 and continues through Sept. 24. On the night of Aug. 28, 3.5 million birds were in flight over Colorado. Many birds are drawn to the artificial lights of buildings along migratory pathways.

articles.title: Pacific taste of the Australian dream goes up in smoke
articles.summary: Pacific taste of the Australian dream goes up in smoke, as Australia is no longer considered a part of the Pacific Rim.      Â   yestardawny.com.au.au is no part of Pacific Rim anymore.

articles.title: Pacific taste of the Australian dream goes up in smoke
articles.summary: Waltera Foxsiamanu was employed in Queensland abattoir as part of the Pacific-Australia Labour Mobility scheme. His family home burnt down and he had to rush back to the Solomon Islands to look after his mother. Now he's stuck in limbo 2000km away. Pacific Islanders can apply for a visa under the PALM scheme for stays up to four years in Australia.

articles.title: Pacific taste of the Australian dream goes up in smoke
articles.author: Dominic Giannini
articles.summary: Waltera Foxsiamanu was employed in Queensland abattoir as part of the Pacific-Australia Labour Mobility scheme. His family home burnt down and he had to rush back to the Solomon Islands to look after his mother. Now he's stuck in limbo 2000km away. Pacific Islanders can apply for a visa under the PALM scheme for stays up to four years in Australia.

articles.title: Rare police shooting reveals how a US imported belief system is becoming more violent in Australia
articles.author: Hilary Whiteman
articles.summary: Dezi Freeman is accused of shooting dead two police officers on Tuesday when they tried to serve a search warrant on his property over alleged sex crimes. He had previously called the police 'Nazis' and 'terrorist thugs' in evidence submitted to court when he tried to overturn a 2020 conviction for traffic offenses. 'Dezi' Freeman is a self-proclaimed 'sovereign citizen' in Australia. The movement originated in the United States and has spread to Australia. Expert Marilyn McMahon estimates there are 2,000 of them in the country.

articles.title: Thawing permafrost raised carbon dioxide levels after the last ice age, study shows
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere vary naturally between ice ages and interglacial periods, according to the International Agency for Research on Climate Change (IARC). IARC: Carbon dioxide levels vary between the ice ages, interglacials, and the present-day.

articles.title: Poll: 41% of parents worried about school safety before Minneapolis shooting
articles.author: Morgan Sweeney
articles.summary: Showers are expected to develop after midnight in Griffin, GA. The weather will be partly cloudy, with a 40% chance of rain. The sky will be cloudy and the wind will be light and variable. The rain is expected to be heavy at times.

articles.title: ‘Catastrophic': Huge update on world's largest iceberg
articles.author: Jamie Seidel
articles.summary: Before July, the world's largest iceberg is falling apart and melting. The West Antarctic Ice Shelf is on the verge of collapse. The East Antarctic Ice Sheet, located closer to Australia, is also showing signs of similar stress. The most obvious sign is the northward march of the orphaned ice.

articles.title: Immigration isn't charity. It's Australia's growth strategy
articles.author: The Examiner
articles.summary: Join the debate on how migration strengthens Australia amidst economic fears and the Indo-Pacific shift at CNN iReport.com/Heroes and join the discussion on migration, economic fears, and the shift to the Pacific Rim. iReport: How does migration strengthen Australia?

articles.title: ‘Strong contrast' between Mountain West states in viewing climate change's impact on severe weather events
articles.author: Rocky Mountain Community Radio
articles.summary: Yale University's Program on Climate Change Communication has surveyed the American public for 17 years. It found that over 60% of Americans think climate change is impacting extreme heat, wildfires, and drought, and 50% think it's affecting hurricanes, flooding, and rising sea levels. Some of the sharpest divides are in the Rocky Mountain West, where 70% of Coloradans think global warming is affecting wildfires, 60% in Utah, and 48% in Wyoming.

articles.title: Stark gap between climate change taught in India and lived experience: report
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: There is a gap between students' lived experiences of climate catastrophes and the climate change taught in schools in India. The report titled 'Towards Quality Climate Change Education For All' claims that the policies on environment and climate science within the National Education Policy 2020 and the National Curriculum Framework 2023 are not successfully implemented. There is a disproportionate impact on women, labour classes and tribal and rural populations from climate change.

articles.title: Antarctica Is Unraveling
articles.author: Gizmodo
articles.summary: "Abrupt changes" threaten to send the continent past the point of no return, a new study finds, as a result of "abrupt changes". The study was published in the journal "Theoretical Geography".    i.e. "Theory of the future of the continent."

articles.title: Great Lakes have entered era of extreme temps, study finds
articles.author: Carlyn Zwarenstein
articles.summary: University of Michigan researchers looked at data sets going back to 1940 and found the Great Lakes are experiencing more extreme temperature swings. Heat waves and cold snaps can affect entire ecosystems, threatening fish. Since the late 1990s, the number of extreme weather events in Great Lakes has more than doubled. Global warming is caused mostly by fossil fuel emissions.

articles.title: More high temperature records broken in B.C. as heat wave continues
articles.author: Ian Holliday
articles.summary: On Thursday, nine places in B.C. saw their hottest August 28 on record, most of them in the Interior. The mercury hit 38.2 C in Cache Creek, surpassing the previous record of 36.8 C set in 2017. Fort St. John broke a much older record with its high of 31.1 C, while the previous mark of 30.6 C dates back 90 years to 1935.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor: Why return kids to school in August?
articles.summary: August is the second hottest month of the year, behind July. Children should be sent back to school on a Labor Day - Memorial Day schedule. Summer tourism and travel opportunities are cut by 33% in August. Practice for many extracurriculars begins prior to the start of "fall" classes.

articles.title: Haryana's Vigilance against Flood Threats: Action Plans in Place
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Nayab Singh Saini has directed all deputy commissioners to assess river-adjacent areas under their watch. The measure is aimed at ensuring accurate water level monitoring and early preparation against potential inundation. The situation is especially dire as multiple areas across Haryana and neighboring Punjab are already experiencing flooding.

articles.title: Punjab farmers left in despair as floods wipe out fields and herds
articles.author: Waseem Abbasi
articles.summary: Floods in Pakistan's Punjab province have killed about 20 people and devastated livelihoods of countless others. In Wazirabad district, more than 25 villages have been submerged and nearly 8,000 residents displaced. Farmers lost their crops and livestock in the floods. The ongoing floods pose a severe threat to Pakistan's already struggling economy.

articles.title: Hate Turbulence? Scientists Say Flying Could Get Even Bumpier
articles.author: Snigdha Oreya
articles.summary: Scientists have warned that climate change and higher temperatures in the future could lead to more severe turbulence on flights. The worst effects of turbulence are visible in the highest greenhouse gas emissions. The scientists expect the CO2 emissions levels to double by 2050 and the average global temperature to rise by 4.4 degrees Celsius by 2100.

articles.title: Microalgae are more significant for CO₂ absorption in Southern Ocean than previously thought, study reveals
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: Algal blooms in the Southern Ocean 14,000 years ago helped to reduce the global carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere. The current and expected future decline in sea ice in this region poses a serious threat to these algae. Phaeocystis is particularly endangered in Antarctica because of sea ice loss.

articles.title: Atlantic Ocean Current Collapse Now a Real Risk
articles.author: Jenn Gidman
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, or AMOC, is at its weakest in 1,600 years. Scientists extended the timeline of climate models to the years 2300 and 2500, beyond the usual 2100 cutoff. 70% of the models show an AMOC collapse, even with moderate emissions. The tipping point could be reached within the next 10 to 20 years.

articles.title: Media Falsely Claim Antarctica On Brink Of Climate Doom, Ignore Contrary Data
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: CBS, ABC and other media outlets are pushing an untenable climate crisis narrative about Antarctica. The data and history of Antarctic ice show that 'abrupt changes' are neither unprecedented nor a reason to panic. Natural variability and cyclical shifts are being ignored in favor of sensational headlines.

articles.title: Bird migration is ramping up in Michigan: Map shows how many are flying
articles.author: Justine Lofton
articles.summary: Millions of birds are flying south across the U.S. en route to their winter homes in the tropics. More than 380 bird species fly through Michigan each year during fall migration. Frank Fabbro of the Whitefish Point Bird Observatory counted 6,609 red-necked grebes flying past the point on August 23.

articles.title: US East Coast at Risk of Sea Level Surge
articles.author: Jasmine Laws
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, also known as AMOC, may collapse within the next 50 to 100 years. The collapse of AMOC would cause major shifts in climate and increase sea levels by 50 cm. The East Coast of the U.S. would be particularly affected by the major rise in sea levels if the AMOC collapses.

articles.title: Atlantic current at risk of COLLAPSE plunging UK into never-ending winter
articles.author: Grace Piercy
articles.summary: The Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) is the main ocean current system in the Atlantic Ocean. New research has found it is at its weakest in 1,600 years due to climate change. If carbon emissions rise, 70% of models ended in the current's collapse by 2100. Even when run on low emissions, models found AMOC had a 25% chance of failure. Scientists have said the collapse of AMOC must be avoided 'at all costs'

articles.title: National Workshop on Wetland Vulnerability and Site Prioritization Opens in Antigua and Barbuda
articles.author: Brent Simon
articles.summary: The Fisheries Division within the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and the Blue Economy in collaboration with IUCN hosted a work session under the theme 'Wise Use of Caribbean Wetlands for Climate Change Mitigation and Conservation of their Ecosystem Services' on August 28th and 29th. Its primary focus is to finalize the climate change vulnerability assessment of Codrington Lagoon, Antigua and Barbuda's designated Ramsar site, and to identify priority adaptation measures for its protection.

articles.title: Don't let the sun go down on me: Vancouver Island sunsets slip before 8 p.m.
articles.author: Tony Trozzo
articles.summary: Evening strolls have been a summer staple across Greater Victoria, but the days of post-work sunsets that last past 8 p.m. are drawing to a close. The official end of summer does not come until Sept. 22, but daylight savings will deal another shift on Nov. 2.

articles.title: From Katrina to Maria: Hurricane season's lasting effects on U.S. minorities
articles.author: Staff Writer
articles.summary: Last week Hurricane Erin became the first major hurricane of the 2025 season. It is estimated that human-caused climate change made the warm water temperature around where Erin formed 90% more likely. This Friday marks exactly 20 years since Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast. It was the costliest hurricane in U.S. history at $125 billion and 1.5 million people were displaced. Hurricane Harvey made landfall near the Texas Gulf Coast in August 2017.

articles.title: SHS pL4d LitCited (The eRulemaking Program)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: USGS National Climate Change Viewer is available at: http://www.usgs.gov/tools/national-climate-change-viewer-nccv. America's Longleaf Restoration Initiative is a project of the USGS. It's about the longleaf pine tree.

articles.title: Climate change driving farmer-herder crises, banditry in Nigeria
articles.author: Franca Ochigbo
articles.summary: Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Environment, Adam Mahmud Kambari, has linked ongoing security challenges in Nigeria to the impacts of climate change. He was speaking at an inception workshop in Abuja on capacity development for conflict-sensitive adaptation and the launch of a report on integrating peacebuilding into Nigeria's National Adaptation Plan.

articles.title: ‘A telltale sign': WNC farmers look to Apple Festival to jumpstart season after devastating year
articles.author: Gerard Albert III
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit Western North Carolina at the peak of apple season last year. The storm destroyed crops, farm equipment and roads leading to the farms. Danielle Stepp-McCall's orchard lost four weeks of its 11-week season. The farm's income was down by 45% compared to 2023. The state started sending funds to farmers affected by the storm.

articles.title: Frost could damage plants overnight
articles.author: Village Media
articles.summary: Temperatures are expected to fall to the freezing mark overnight. Frost advisory is issued for: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Ont., Elliot Lake, Ranger Lake, Timmins, Cochrane, Iroquois Falls, Chapleau, Gogama, Kirkland Lake, Temiskaming Shores, Temagami, Ont.

articles.title: Federal Gov't To Integrate Peace-building Into National Adaptation Plan
articles.author: Leadership News
articles.summary: The Federal Ministry of Environment has formally launched the Report of Integrating Conflict-Sensitivity and Peacebuilding into Nigeria's National Adaptation Plan (NAP) process. The director of Department of Climate Change, Ministry Environment, Dr. Iniobong Abiola-Awe, said Nigeria is formulating its NAP as a means of identifying medium to long-term adaptation needs.

articles.title: More than 3.5 million birds migrated over Colorado in 1 night this week. Residents are being asked to turn out their lights to help them
articles.author: Ryan Spencer
articles.summary: Lights Out Colorado reminds Colorado residents to turn out their outdoor lights during the bird migration. The peak bird migration starts on Sept. 1 and continues through Sept. 24. On the night of Aug. 28, 3.5 million birds were flying over Colorado. Many birds are drawn to the artificial lights of buildings along migratory pathways.

articles.title: ARTE Europe Weekly: How Can Europe Get Wildfires Under Control?
articles.author: Balkan Insight
articles.summary: In 2025, more land has been burnt by forest fires in Europe than ever before. Experts are calling for a drastic change of approach to forest fire management.       in 2025,  in Europe there will be more forest fires than before.

articles.title: Rising Waters: Evacuations Ordered Near Tangri River
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Officials in Ambala Cantonment, led by Haryana Minister Anil Vij, are responding to dangerously rising water levels in the Tangri river following heavy rainfalls in Himachal Pradesh. Schools near the river have been closed, and residents are being advised to evacuate vulnerable areas.

articles.title: How planes continue to fly in icy conditions
articles.summary: There are processes in place to ensure that planes continue to be able to fly in wintry conditions. A buildup of ice snow or ice on the wings of a plane can have serious consequences for the pilot's ability to fly it. Check out the gallery to find out more.

articles.title: Collapse Of Critical Atlantic Current Is No Longer Low-Likelihood, Study Finds
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: The Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (Amoc) is a major part of the global climate system. It brings sun-warmed tropical water to Europe and the Arctic, where it cools and sinks to form a deep return current. The Amoc was already known to be at its weakest in 1,600 years as a result of the climate crisis.

articles.title: Scientists Make Surprising Find About Arctic Sea Ice Loss
articles.author: Thomas Westerholm
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice has experienced a dramatic slowdown in its rate of decline over the past two decades. However, scientists attribute the change to internal climate variability rather than a shift in long-term trends. Expert opinion was unanimous in stressing that the findings do not undermine the reality or urgency of climate change.

articles.title: The summer of smoke
articles.author: Tricia Clarkson
articles.summary: Both 2023 and 2025 experienced significant summers of smoke in Ontario due to widespread wildfire smoke from Quebec and western Canada. The 2025 wildfire season in Canada is already the second-worst on record. It was the summer of smoke, drought, extreme heat and poor air quality in Ontario and most of Canada this year.

articles.title: Climate crisis on stage at Arkas Art Alaçatı
articles.author: Al Monitor
articles.summary: Climate crisis on stage at Arkas Art Alaçat Istanbul. Al-Monitor is in Cesme and Alacati, twin escapes an hour from Izmir. They discuss the climate crisis, the nausea of existence and farm-to-table plates.

articles.title: Katrina inspired a $3B wetlands rebuilding project. Louisiana just killed it.
articles.summary: The Mid-Barataria project was a key component of Louisiana's coastal plan under Republican Gov. Bobby Jindal and remained so when Democrat John Bel Edwards took office in 2016. Landry, a close ally of President Donald Trump who became governor in 2024, cancelled the project.

articles.title: 20 years ago Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans. The Trump administration couldn't handle a storm of that size, say its own employees
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: Experts believe FEMA is ill-prepared to respond to a major hurricane like Katrina. President Donald Trump wants to dismantle the agency. FEMA was criticized over its response to Katrina and the actions of its leadership. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem wants to streamline the agency and reduce red tape.

articles.title: The Science behind Hurricane Katrina: What Researchers Knew before the 2005 Disaster
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: Two decades after Katrina, we revisit the storm and discuss the evolution of hurricane preparedness since that time.    "It's been two decades since Katrina. It's been a long time since that happened."  "Hurricane preparedness has evolved since then."

articles.title: Air Cleanliness Matters To Your Health
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Sudden climate change is one of the most complex issues people face. The intricacy will be around for decades and probably centuries to come. Before we dwell on the global warming that perpetrates the sophistication of all the causes, let's think about all the different factors involved.

articles.title: Florida's once-pristine springs threatened by pollution, development and climate change
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Florida's once-pristine springs are threatened by development, pollution, development and climate change, according to the AP News report.    .  Â   in Florida's once pristine springs are now threatened by pollution and development, development, climate change.

articles.title: Don't let the sun go down on me: Victoria sunsets slip before 8 p.m.
articles.author: Tony Trozzo Victoria News
articles.summary: Evening strolls have been a summer staple across Greater Victoria, but the days of post-work sunsets that last past 8 p.m. are drawing to a close. The official end of summer does not come until Sept. 22, but daylight savings will deal another shift on Nov. 2.

articles.title: Kenya's Uneven Rains Threaten Food Security, Energy Stability And Fiscal Space
articles.author: Steve Biko Wafula
articles.summary: ICPAC's OND (October–December) forecast suggests an increased likelihood of below-average rains for eastern Kenya and the eastern Horn, while western corridors are more likely to receive wetter-than-normal conditions. Western Kenya (counties Bungoma, Kakamega, and parts of Trans Nzoia and Vihiga) sits in the green on the ICPAC map. Turkana, Marsabit, Samburu, Isiolo, Garissa, Tana River, Kitui and Wajir are in the below-normal band. If the OND forecast verifies, the humanitarian caseload for food assistance and cash transfers is likely to

articles.title: East Africa Faces Uneven Rains As Food Security Is Threatened
articles.author: Steve Biko
articles.summary: East Africa is heading into a season of uneven rainfall patterns that could reshape food security, energy generation, and cross-border trade. The latest forecast from IGAD's Climate Prediction and Applications Centre shows a patchwork of excess rains, prolonged dryness, and transition zones. Western Kenya, northern Uganda, and parts of southern Sudan are projected to receive above-normal rainfall. The vast swathes of Kenya's arid and semi-arid lands are colored orange, with a 60% probability of below-normal rain.

articles.title: Africa: The Second Africa Climate Summit (Acs2) Announces Advanced Preparations for a Landmark Summit
articles.summary: The Second Africa Climate Summit (ACS2) is taking place from 8-10 September 2025 at the Addis International Convention Center (AICC), Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The deadline for media accreditation is August 31, 2025. The registration for hosting side events and pavilions has already been closed. Delegates and media are encouraged to register early.

articles.title: Friday letters: Private jets, Hershey response, speeding concerns and more
articles.summary: The world's wealthiest 10% are responsible for two-thirds of global heating since 1990. The super-rich 1% were responsible for more carbon emissions than 66% of humanity. The global fleet of private jets has increased 133% in the last two decades, with a record 5.3 million business jet operations. The Swedish use the term flygskam to name abusers.

articles.title: Hurricane Katrina Revealed Why Climate Justice Must Include the Right to Free Movement
articles.author: Resilience
articles.summary: Katrina taught us that climate migration is not a natural phenomenon. It's not a migration of people, it's a phenomenon of climate change. It is not migration of species, it is a change of species. It can be caused by humans or by natural disasters.

articles.title: Australia, Indonesia reject Israeli actions in Gaza, call for ceasefire, aid delivery
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Australia and Indonesia have condemned Israeli actions in Gaza. They warn that any attempts to alter the territory's demographic composition or make its occupation permanent are illegal and must cease immediately. In a joint statement, the two countries warn that Israel's actions are unlawful and must be stopped immediately.

articles.title: Punjab Unites: Coordinated Flood Relief Efforts Across Districts
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Rescue and relief efforts are underway in flood-stricken areas of Punjab. Chief Minister Bhagwant Mann has commanded the acceleration of relief measures. Rescue teams are using boats and amphibious vehicles to evacuate stranded residents to safer locations. Political figures have committed their salaries to support flood victims. Community leaders are urging citizens to collaborate actively in relief and rehabilitation.

articles.title: Georgia Bolsters Defenses for Climate Resilience
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Georgia is fortifying its resilience through a US$74 million programme implemented by the UNDP and the Government of Georgia. Climate change poses a significant threat to Georgia, manifesting in more frequent and severe floods, landslides, mudflows, and droughts. The ambitious seven-year initiative is generously funded by the Green Climate Fund (GCF), the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), and the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida).

articles.title: Key Atlantic current on verge of collapse, sparking a global emergency
articles.author: Chris Melore
articles.summary: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could collapse after 2100, especially if greenhouse gas emissions remain high, according to research team from Europe. AMOC keeps parts of the world from freezing over, but it's at risk of completely shutting down within decades.

articles.title: Key Atlantic current on verge of collapse, sparking a global emergency
articles.author: Chris Melore
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could collapse after 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions remain high. The AMOC is like a conveyor belt that moves warm water from the tropics to the northern Atlantic. It helps keep places like northwestern Europe and the northeastern US milder in winter and influences weather patterns worldwide. If the AMOC shuts down, it could cause colder winters and drier summers in the Northeast, raise sea levels along the East Coast, and disrupt fishing industries for American businesses.

articles.title: Bihar's Climate Risks: A Detailed District Assessment
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Bihar, India, is at the forefront of the climate change crisis. The study focuses on district-level assessments of climate trends, projections, exposure to climate hazards, and the vulnerabilities inherent to the region. It highlights the socio-economic factors that compound climate risks in Bihar. Poverty, limited access to information, and inadequate infrastructure exacerbate the vulnerability of the population. There is an urgent call for actionable climate policies that align with the needs of Bihar's communities.

articles.title: North Carolina has the fourth-highest projected annual loss from hurricanes in the U.S.
articles.author: Pre News
articles.summary: North Carolina has the fourth-highest projected annual loss from hurricanes in the U.S. at $1.76 billion. Florida, Louisiana and South Carolina have higher expected losses. The study used data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration National Centers for Environmental Information.

articles.title: CM Maryam appeals people to cooperate with admin
articles.author: Dr Saadia Hanif
articles.summary: Maryam Nawaz Sharif urges people living in flood-prone areas to cooperate with the administration and immediately move to safer locations. She assures the public that losses to homes, crops and livestock are being carefully assessed and the government is committed to providing fair compensation.

articles.title: What is a solar flare? Everything you need to know
articles.summary: Solar flares are storms that take place on the surface of the Sun. Fluctuations to the magnetic field can sometimes be felt as far away as here on Earth. Click on to discover the potential impact of solar storms on Earth and find out if we should be worried.

articles.title: Common Pain Meds Could Be Contributing To Antibiotic Resistance
articles.summary: There will be some sun this morning with increasing clouds this afternoon. There will be a chance of a rain shower. The weather will be cloudy with 70% chance of rain overnight. The temperature will drop to around 66F with light and variable winds. The area will see occasional showers.

articles.title: Researchers fear climate stress is changing bee behavior and threatening global pollination
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise under climate change, scientists are trying to better understand the effects on managed and wild bees as they pollinate crops, gather nectar, make honey and reproduce. Bees are heat-tolerant, but as the climate warms, some experts think their ability to fend off disease and gather food might become harder.

articles.title: Oceana Pier remains closed this Labor Day weekend after damage from Hurricane Erin
articles.author: Pre News
articles.summary: The Oceana Pier remains closed this Labor Day weekend after damage from Hurricane Erin. The inspection is expected to take place next week and the pier will be closed until at least Wednesday. The Pier House Restaurant is open with its normal fall hours. The Barnacle bar is closed until the pier is reopened.

articles.title: Wildfires And Pollution Are Solvable. They'll Be Worse With Inaction
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Warming climate is making forests hotter and drier. This poisons forests and makes fire conditions worse. Wildfires are growing every year due to the warming climate and the increase of forest fires.    i.e. because of climate change, forest fires are getting worse.

articles.title: Thousands of 'winter migrant' birds flocking to UK gardens from September
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Bird watchers will be able to see thousands of migrants flocking back to the UK this winter. Redwings and fieldfares are the most common migrants. Bramblings, Bewick's swans and whooper swans are also coming back from Scandinavia. Waxwings come back from Europe if the crop is poor.

articles.title: Can new farming methods reduce greenhouse gases? Georgia Tech professor looks answers
articles.author: The Augusta Chronicle
articles.summary: Hurricanes can release hazardous materials from sewage treatment plants and agricultural runoff. Liming, a common agricultural practice, removes carbon from the atmosphere. Georgia Tech study finds that liming removes CO2 from the air, water, soil, and even from the environment.

articles.title: The Supposed Nearly Unanimous Consensus on Climate Change Was A High Stakes Pernicious Deception
articles.author: Vijay Jayaraj
articles.summary: When researchers abandon empirical observation in favor of predetermined conclusions, science transforms into propaganda. Authentic scientists faced systematic marginalization for questioning the prevailing narrative. Dr. Judith Curry, professor emerita at Georgia Institute of Technology, was one of the authors of the July U.S. Department of Energy report 'A Critical Review of Impacts of Greenhouse Gas Emissions on the U.s. Climate'.

articles.title: The Disaster Is Coming From Inside FEMA
articles.summary: In the midst of hurricane season, dismayed former and current FEMA staffers warn of another Katrina, according to former and present staffers. They are worried about another hurricane season.       .   "Another Katrina" is a reference to Hurricane Katrina.

articles.title: Urgent Concern as Critical Atlantic Ocean Current Nears Possible Breakdown
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is at risk of completely shutting down within decades if greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise. The AMOC is an ocean conveyor belt that transports warm water from the tropics to the northern Atlantic. The Gulf Stream is crucial in this system, serving as the primary current that carries warm water along the US East Coast, moving northward. A shutdown of the AMOC could lead to colder winters and drier summers in the Northeast, elevate sea levels along the East Coast and negatively impact the fishing industries of American enterprises.

articles.title: Labor can't subsidise its way through energy transition
articles.author: Chris Bowen
articles.summary: The conservatives' approach to energy and the environment in recent years has been a political car crash. The left and right of the parliamentary gallery can't look away from the conservatives' climate policy. Peter Dutton's defeat in May has attracted more attention to the conservative approach to the environment.

articles.title: Atlantic Ocean current system could collapse by 2030s, study finds
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean current system that regulates global weather patterns could collapse as early as the late 2030s. The combined impact of the shutdown of the AMOC and global warming could make temperatures in northern Europe akin to those in the Ice Age, according to the study.

articles.title: Letter: No. Don't let the markets decide!
articles.author: Robert Sells
articles.summary: The commentary 'Let the Market Decide' criticized solar panels because their cost was offset by government subsidiaries and they cover more land surface than oil or coal installations. Fossil fuels emit carbon dioxide that causes a dangerous rise in temperature. The increase in world-wide temperature negatively impacts our environment, our weather and our lives.

articles.title: Sydney sets rain record, warned to brace for more to come
articles.author: Luke Kinsella
articles.summary: Sydney just experienced its third-rainiest August since 1930. It's the wettest four-year period in more than 100 years. Experts say climate change is causing the tropics to expand, bringing the wild weather they are famous for further south.

articles.title: New Orleans marks 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina with memorials and brass band parade
articles.summary: On August 29, 2025, New Orleans will honor two decades since Hurricane Katrina struck with memorial events, artistic performances and a traditional brass band second line parade. The commemoration includes a healing ceremony in the Lower Ninth Ward, panel discussions on recovery, museum exhibits, documentary screenings, and a rally featuring local artists and prayers.

articles.title: Co-ordinated plan needed to save ‘alarmingly low' monarch butterfly population: study
articles.summary: The monarch butterfly's population has decreased by 80 per cent in the past two decades. The loss of breeding habitat is cited as the main reason behind the sharp decline. Researchers urge Canada, United States and Mexico to take immediate action to save the monarch butterfly as it faces a growing risk of extinction.

articles.title: Calls To Action On Cutting Contrails Grow
articles.author: Guy Norris
articles.summary: Time is running out to mitigate the impact of contrails on atmospheric warming, according to an international research study. There remains some uncertainty about the global effect of the clouds formed by high-flying aircraft, but there is some evidence that contrails are warming the atmosphere.

articles.title: Severe flooding hits at Kaleshwaram Triveni confluence amid rains
articles.author: Pavan Bandari
articles.summary: Heavy rainfall has caused flooding in the Godavari region. Floodwaters have surpassed the initial warning threshold in Kaleshwaram Triveni confluence. Hundreds of acres of cotton have been submerged. Local farmers are worried about the loss of their cotton crops for the second consecutive year.

articles.title: PDMA urges immediate removal of encroachments from river passages
articles.author: Abid Khan
articles.summary: 20 people have died in flood-related incidents in Punjab. More than 317,000 animals have been shifted to safer locations. The Punjab government will provide Rs. 1 million in financial assistance to the families of those who lost their lives in the floods. The recent floods have damaged crops in the passageways of both Ravi and Sutlej rivers.

articles.title: Viewpoint: Wildfire smoke signals growing climate crisis
articles.author: Missoula Current
articles.summary: A group of Republican members of Congress sent a letter to the Canadian government, accusing them of poor forest management practices and out-of-control wildfires. The letter does not mention climate change. According to Natural Resources Canada, warmer-than-average temperatures, decreased levels of snowpack, low soil moisture and elevated drought conditions are indicators that climate change is impacting the frequency, size and range of wildland fires in Canada. In the 2015 issue of the U.S. Forest Service's journal, Fire Management Today, the journal states that increasing temperatures and changes in precipitation and snowmelt patterns are increasing the severity and size of wildfires in the West.

articles.title: Expert fears for wildlife as North York Moors fire continues
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: The moorland fire on Langdale has been burning for 18 days. It's burned 10 sq miles (25 sq km) of land and has had a "devastating" impact on local wildlife, an expert has said. Firefighters have been tackling the blaze.

articles.title: Rising Lake Turkana swallows villages, crocodile attacks add to misery
articles.author: Sammy Lutta
articles.summary: The rising waters of Lake Turkana have destroyed homes, ruined livelihoods and driven entire communities to the brink of disaster. Mike Ekusi, a father of five from Apokorit village, has been forced to relocate more than ten times since 2020 due to the rising waters. In Kerio Delta Ward, entire villages have been flooded, forcing residents to flee to higher ground. Crocodiles are also a threat to people living near the lake.

articles.title: The rising risk of wildfires – And the impact on business travelers
articles.author: Travel Daily News
articles.summary: Sixty-two percent of business travelers worry about natural disasters when they travel. Wildfires are emerging as one of the most unpredictable and fast-growing threats. The United States, Chile, Australia, Canada, and other countries are at risk of wildfires. The seasonality is breaking down.

articles.title: Not just Venice is sinking! Here's the list of world's most famous cities at risk of going underwater by 2100
articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.summary: Global warming and climate change are accelerating the rise of sea levels worldwide. Low-lying coastal cities are already witnessing devastating floods. Jakarta is sinking at a rate of up to 6.7 inches per year due to groundwater pumping. The Indonesian government approved a $33 billion plan to move Jakarta 100 miles away from its current location on Java Island. Without drastic measures, much of Jakarta could be underwater by 2050. Lagos is at serious risk of flooding due to rising seas. Bangkok is sinking more than 1 cm per year. New Orleans is sinking by about 2 inches a year.

articles.title: Israeli intel helped Australia uncover Iran's role in antisemitic attacks – The Times of Israel
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Israel gave investigators lead on a firebombing. Sky News Australia says it shows intelligence-sharing still strong despite diplomatic spat with Israel. .       .   Google Alert – Israel. Google Alert: Israel. iReport.com.

articles.title: Varanasi's Battle with Rising Water: Floods and Resilience
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Rising water levels in the Ganga and Varuna rivers have triggered a new wave of floods in the historic city of Varanasi. Traditional rituals like cremations and the famous 'Ganga Aarti' have been relocated to rooftops, while residents in Ramana and Nagwa find themselves grappling with floodwater.

articles.title: Another New Study Suggests Most – 80% – Of The Modern CO2 Increase Has Been Natural
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: At least 80% of the modern CO2 increase is of natural origin. Sea surface temperature (SST) determines annual changes in atmospheric CO2 concentrations. Anthropogenic emissions have been irrelevant in this process, according to Ato, a peer-reviewed journal.

articles.title: Wind farm fans 'death row' fears for endangered species
articles.author: .M-A-Box
articles.summary: ACEN Australia's 100-turbine wind farm proposal for Robbins Island in Tasmania has been approved. The project was stalled for eight years. Environment Minister Murray Watt said Australia has to be 'realistic' about the need for renewable energy. Environmentalists raised concerns about the project's impact on local wildlife. Christine Milne, a former Greens politician, slammed the decision.

articles.title: Labor greenlights contentious Robbins Island windfarm despite fears for endangered orange-bellied parrot
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Environment advocates have called for important migratory shorebird habitat off Tasmania to be declared 'no-go site' for conservationists.       for the endangered migratory bird species off the Tasmanian coast. For more news, visit the Australia news live blog.

articles.title: Relief for millions of Aussies as spring weather likely to see 'exciting' phenomenon: 'A really good sign'
articles.author: Courtney Greatrex
articles.summary: A negative Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is developing off Australia's coast. It will bring above-average rainfall for most of eastern and central Australia. October is expected to bring the strongest signal for wet conditions, with the chance of unusually heavy downpours in the top 20% of spring totals historically. Northern Australia will transition from dry to wet season from September to November, while southern Western Australia will remain drier than usual.

articles.title: When Patriotism Just Isn't Cricket
articles.author: Fred Pawle
articles.summary: Pat Cummins and Usman Khawaja had private meetings with PM Anthony Albanese this week to discuss climate change and Israel's food blockade in Gaza. The PM is busy and stressed because of the upcoming Australian flag march on Sunday. Immigration Minister Tony Burke took the majority of the burden by vilifying those who like the country the way it is.

articles.title: Malawi Combines AI and Community Action to Build Stronger Climate Resilience
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Malawi is at a turning point in its climate governance. The Meteorological Bill is under review, a new Climate Policy is in development, and the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services is finalizing its Strategic Plan (2025–2030). The Disaster Risk Management Act is being operationalized, strengthening the institutional framework for disaster preparedness. Out of 100 weather stations across the country, only 28 are fully operational.

articles.title: Devastating Rains and Landslides Ravage Uttarakhand
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Severe weather conditions have caused landslides in Chamoli, Rudraprayag and Tehri districts of Uttarakhand. Several people are missing under the debris. The ongoing monsoon season has brought significant hardship to the region, exacerbated by blocked highways and devastated agricultural lands.

articles.title: Stemming the tide: how seashells can restore Tai O's coastal habitat
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: As Hong Kong's typhoon season approaches, climate change could intensify the strength of tropical storms, bringing disaster in their wake. Low-lying areas such as Tai O, a coastal town, could be at risk of being hit by a typhoon.

articles.title: Flights may experience more air turbulence under continued global warming: Study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: A stronger wind shear is created in jet streams due to climate change. The atmosphere at altitudes where aircraft fly could become more turbulent under a continued warming of the planet, making the air less stable and increasing the risk of turbulence, according to a new study.

articles.title: Kitui farmers advised to get right seeds as poor short rains predicted
articles.author: MUSEMBI NZENGU
articles.summary: Kitui County farmers have been warned to take early precautions after new forecasts warned of another season of poor rains. The warning is especially concerning for Kitui, where the March–May rains were also below average, leaving many farmers staring at massive crop losses. The Igad Climate Prediction and Applications Centre projected that most of Eastern Kenya will be drier and warmer than usual.

articles.title: Europe faces record-breaking wildfires as climate change worsens 2025 season
articles.author: Times
articles.summary: Europe is witnessing a record-breaking wildfire season in 2025. Experts blame climate change for the increase in the intensity of the wildfire season.   in Euro News reported that experts attribute the increase to climate change.  in Brussels.  In Paris, experts blame the rise in the number of wildfires on the increase of the temperature.

articles.title: Drowning nations: Kiribati and the South Pacific's fight for survival
articles.author: Michelle Mckeown
articles.summary: Kiribati is one of the lowest-lying countries in the world. Its atolls rise barely two metres above sea level. Sea levels in the Pacific are rising faster than the global average. Kiribati's government has pursued the strategy of 'migration with dignity'. It purchased 20 square kilometres of land in Fiji as a potential site for food production.

articles.title: Australian Living in UK Says There's One Rule that 'Makes No Sense'
articles.author: Daily Mirror
articles.summary: An Australian woman living in the UK shares the things that 'baffle' her, such as accents and the size of seagulls. She is not a great fan of the British accent or of the size and shape of seabulls, however.

articles.title: 5 of the best things to do in Hong Kong this weekend August 29-31
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Temperatures are still above 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit) most days. According to the 24 terms in the solar calendar, the temperature is above freezing according to terms 24 and 25 of the calendar's terms.    It may not feel like it, but according to the terms 24 terms of calendar it is.

articles.title: Devastating Floods in Punjab: Over 1.46 Million Affected as Rivers Overflow
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Pakistan's Punjab province is experiencing its worst flooding in decades. At least 17 people have died in the deluge. More than 1.46 million people have been affected and 265,000 have been evacuated. The flooding has submerged 991 villages and affected over a million people.

articles.title: Stemming the tide: how seashells can restore Tai O's coastal habitat
articles.author: Morning Studio Editors
articles.summary: Tai O, a fishing village on Lantau Island, is at risk of extreme weather events due to climate change. A Plastic Ocean Foundation (APO) is leading an initiative to promote sustainable coastal management. The installation of modular wire reefs along Tai O's shore helps reduce wave impact, supports habitat restoration and lowers flood risk.

articles.title: Global warming is winning while we are smiling
articles.author: Quamrul Haider
articles.summary: The year 2024 was the hottest year ever recorded, with global temperatures averaging 1.52 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels for the first time. Global carbon dioxide emissions surged to an all-time high in 2024. Global average temperature will be 3-5 degrees Celsius higher by the end of this century.

articles.title: Climate Inquisition Silenced a Generation of Scientists
articles.author: Vijay Jayaraj
articles.summary: When researchers abandon empirical observation in favor of predetermined conclusions, science transforms into propaganda. Authentic scientists have been marginalized for questioning the prevailing narrative. Dr. Judith Curry, professor emerita at Georgia Institute of Technology, was one of the authors of the July U.S. Department of Energy report "A Critical Review of Impacts of Greenhouse Gas Emissions on the U.s. Climate".

articles.title: Antarctica is a growing tourist hotspot. But getting there comes at a cost
articles.author: Jano Gibson
articles.summary: There are more than 100,000 international tourists who visit Antarctica every year, including almost 10,000 Australians. Getting there usually involves long-haul flights from the United States, Europe, Asia and Australia, followed by a cruise that can last days or weeks. According to a new study, flights and cruises over the 2022–23 tourist season generated 674,696 tonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions.

articles.title: Agriculture stakeholders chart future in climate foresight workshop
articles.summary: Agriculture stakeholders are taking part in a climate foresight workshop today. The aim of the initiative is to chart a course for a resilient and sustainable agricultural sector. The workshop was facilitated by the Caribbean Community Climate Change Center (Five Cs) and the Research Triangle Institute (RTI) International.

articles.title: Shanghai locals seek to beat the heat at indoor skiing resort, China News
articles.summary: Temperatures hit 37 degrees Celsius in Shanghai on Thursday. Thousands of people flocked to one of the world's largest indoor ski resorts in the Chinese city. Shanghai has experienced a record 23 consecutive days of temperatures at 35 degrees Celsius or above in August. High temperatures are expected to continue for the rest of the month.

articles.title: Animated Map Reveals Earth's Seasonal Complexity
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The seasons set the rhythm of life. Living things adjust the timing of their annual activities to exploit resources and conditions that fluctuate through the year. A new approach for observing seasonal growth cycles from satellites reveals "hotspots" of seasonal asynchrony around the world, which can have surprising ecological, evolutionary, and even economic consequences.

articles.title: Farmers report mixed outlook for year ahead
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: Sentiment in Australia's agricultural sector has softened over the winter months due to higher input costs and mixed seasonal conditions, according to the latest Rabobank Rural Confidence Survey. The survey was conducted over the last three months.    - RABobank.

articles.title: Wildfire emissions across EU countries hit record high
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: There have been more than 1 million hectares burned since January, an area larger than Cyprus. The large quantities of smoke and PM2.5 released into the atmosphere have resulted in severely degraded air quality in the Iberian Peninsula and parts of France, especially in the south.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning after discovering major impact of microscopic organisms on Arctic ice: 'Darkening'
articles.author: Kritiksha Sharma
articles.summary: Arctic glaciers are shrinking faster than expected. Microbes living in Arctic snow and ice are playing an outsized role in how quickly glaciers melt. Some of these organisms produce dark pigments that stain the ice, causing it to absorb more heat and melt faster. Each summer, a darkened zone roughly the size of Iceland forms on Greenland's ice sheet, contributing as much as 13% of its annual runoff. The Greenland ice sheet contains enough water to raise global sea levels by more than 20 feet.

articles.title: Drop dead
articles.author: Ian Plimer
articles.summary: For more than 80 per cent of time, Earth has been an ice-free warm wet greenhouse planet. We are currently in an ice age that started 34 million years ago. There have been five major mass extinctions of life and dozens of minor extinctions. Most of the planet's methane emissions are from the tundra and tropical forests. Australia emits one molecule of carbon dioxide for every 6.6 million molecules in the atmosphere. Australia is already at Net Zero.

articles.title: New report shows air pollution could cut lives short by more than two years if levels were sustained
articles.summary: In 2023, Canada recorded its worst air pollution in 25 years, according to a new report. The report also looks at how climate change can fuel pollution. The smoke from wildfires in the N.W.T. two years ago will remind people how bad the wildfires were.

articles.title: Heat Waves Can Accelerate Aging as Much as Smoking or Drinking, Study Shows
articles.author: David Nield
articles.summary: A new study shows that heat waves can age the body as much as regular drinking or smoking. The study looked at data from 24,922 Taiwanese people who had undergone medical examinations between 2008 and 2022. Those who had been exposed to more heat waves had higher scores for biological markers associated with aging. By 2050, some 16 percent of people worldwide are expected to be aged 65 or over.

articles.title: Global emergency as key Atlantic current is on the brink of collapse
articles.author: CHRIS MELORE
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could collapse after 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions remain high. The AMOC is like a conveyor belt that moves warm water from the tropics to the northern Atlantic. It helps keep parts of the world milder in winter and influences weather patterns worldwide. If the AMOC shuts down, it could cause colder winters and drier summers in the Northeast, raise sea levels along the East Coast and disrupt fishing industries for American businesses.

articles.title: Farmers on the challenges facing the agricultural industry
articles.author: Chloe Boden
articles.summary: It's been one of the hottest summers on record with below average rainfall across the UK. Dorset has been hit by the first bout of heavy rain this week for months. Farmers are bracing themselves for a hard winter as the scorching weather of the summer has taken its toll on the agricultural industry. Melplash Agricultural Society organise the annual event to encourage young people to pursue careers in the industry.

articles.title: Disaster foresight
articles.author: Dr Babar Shahbaz
articles.summary: The recent floods in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa caught the government and local communities off guard. Climate change-related extreme events are among the most serious challenges facing humanity in the twenty-first century. Pakistan is one of the most climate change vulnerable countries. According to the Global Climate Risk Index, Pakistan was ranked the fifth most vulnerable country in 2023-24. Pakistan has pursued mitigation and adaptation through consistent policy measures.

articles.title: WAKES: A structural threat
articles.summary: There is a growing concern about the impact of wake surf boats on local waterways. William Lavalvin is concerned about the increasing shoreline erosion caused by their large, manufactured wakes. He urges local officials and community leaders to consider the following actions: Implement a wave impact report to raise awareness of high-wake activity and update wake regulations. Engage with boat dealers to encourage responsible sales practices.

articles.title: The Brutal Clouds
articles.summary: Floods and cloudbursts in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa killed hundreds of people and destroyed entire villages. Javeria Hassan, Hassan Zahid, and Hassan Hassan are concerned about climate change. Donald Trump is using trade leverage and tariff threats to pressure Pakistan and India into a ceasefire.

articles.title: Climate Change: FG Seeks Collaboration For Nigeria's Food Safety
articles.author: Telegraph-Admin
articles.summary: The FGN/IFAD Best Practice Workshop on Public-Private Partnerships for Climate Information Services and Consultations on the ClimateSmart Agribusiness Partnership for Resilience (CSAPR) Project took place in Abuja recently. The theme of the workshop is both forward-looking and urgent.

articles.title: India amongst countries hit as deforestation drives 28,000 heat deaths
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: India is one of the countries hit by deforestation that drives heat deaths due to climate change. India is among the worst affected countries.    for the heat deaths caused by deforestation. for more information, go to: http://www.cdc.org/deforestation.

articles.title: Long-range forecast predicts wet spring for most of Australia
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Eastern and central Australia are likely to experience above-average rainfall in the upcoming spring. The long-range forecast for spring was released by the Bureau of Meteorology on Thursday. The season starts on Monday and is expected to be warm and wet in the region.

articles.title: Heatwaves, wildfires and the hot summers that could change how we holiday
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are causing chaos worldwide, so tourists are wondering where to go on holiday in a world on fire. The answer is "Where shall we go on holidays?"   Â.  Н. М. "What does it mean to be a tourist in this world?"

articles.title: UK heatwaves: Millions suffered sleepless nights and stress this summer
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Dolphins leap in the sea off Cullercoats Bay as England enters its fourth sweltering heatwave in a row.    PA.  PA  PA.  PGA. PA. PA,  PA, PGA,

articles.title: UT Study Finds Reduced Aerosols in the Air Leads to More Heat Waves
articles.author: Blake Leschber
articles.summary: As heat waves become more frequent around the world, researchers at UT-Austin found that the decline of aerosols in the atmosphere could be increasing the frequency of prolonged temperature extremes, especially in densely populated areas. Aerosols reflect sunlight and make clouds brighter, which cools the planet. South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa will be hit the hardest by the decline in aerosol emissions due to their higher levels of pollution. Central Texas could see the same effects.

articles.title: Record breaking summer has been 'one of the most challenging' ever for fire service
articles.author: Bournemouth Echo
articles.summary: The large number of fires are the result of extended dry spells, heatwaves, and high winds. The conditions have created the perfect conditions for wildfires to ignite and spread rapidly. The fires are caused by the combination of dry spells and heatwaves. The weather is very dry.

articles.title: Climate leadership or climate delusion
articles.author: Arju Manara Begum
articles.summary: A new study shows that most of the world's biggest carbon emitters are not on track to meet their climate commitments. China, the United States, India, Russia, Japan, Iran, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Canada, South Korea and Germany account for the lion's share of global CO₂ emissions. The most alarming trajectories belong to Iran and Saudi Arabia.

articles.title: CARTOONS: Barnaby Joyce is turning red over renewables
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: Mark David has been at the NSW Bush Summit. He teaches you how to draw cartoons on his YouTube channel. You can see more of his cartoons on the website, Mark David Cartoons, or follow him on Twitter/X @mdavidcartoons.

articles.title: The UK coastal areas daytrippers are flocking to via train
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Polar bears cool down in Yorkshire lake as UK braces another heatwave, according to PPA.    PA.  PA   PPA  Pa. PA   Pa  PA,  PA,.  PA, PA, PA.

articles.title: Study: Climate change worsens Europe fires
articles.author: Winston-Salem Journal
articles.summary: Climate change made massive wildfires in Turkey, Greece and Cyprus burn more fiercely this summer, according to a new study released by Greece's Hellenic Meteorological Agency.    ...   "Climate change that drove scorching temperatures and dwindling rainfall made wildfires burn much more fiercely"

articles.title: Scott Dance Joins the Climate Desk (The New York Times Company)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Scott Dance has documented the impacts of global warming for The Washington Post and before that for The Baltimore Sun. Scott Dance will cover climate adaptation because nations have not reduced greenhouse gases enough to reduce the global warming.    .   for the Washington Post.

articles.title: Unlocking climate innovation in Tanzania: why access to finance is the missing link
articles.author: Sierra Leone Telegraph
articles.summary: In the tide-worn fishing villages of Zanzibar, seaweed farming is both a lifeline and legacy. Coastal Biotech is working at the cutting edge of marine science and climate resilience to help smallholder farmers on the island. The company's seaweed-based bio-stimulants helped improve crop resilience.

articles.title: Wildfire risk expected to rise over B.C.'s long weekend as hot, dry weather continues
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Hot, dry conditions could drive increased fire activity through the Labour Day long weekend in British Columbia. The number of blazes in the province continues to climb.    iReport.com: What do you know about British Columbia's wildfires? Share your information.

articles.title: Global emergency as key Atlantic current is on the brink of collapse
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could collapse after 2100, especially if greenhouse gas emissions remain high. The AMOC is a critical ocean current that keeps parts of the world from freezing over and is at risk of completely shutting down within decades.

articles.title: Will Gaza free America from Israeli control?
articles.author: Arab News
articles.summary: Bob Carr, Australia's former foreign minister, talks about the pro-Palestine protests in Australia and the government's decision to cut ties with Iran over its alleged role in some obscure arson attacks on Jewish premises. He talks about it in an interview with Bob Carr.

articles.title: US East Coast at Risk of Sea Level Surge
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: The rise in sea levels could have major implications for the East Coast. There could be increased flooding and storms due to the rise in water levels. The rise is due to increase in sea level rise.    - The International Agency for Research on Climate Change.

articles.title: How worried are you about climate change?
articles.summary: A new survey found that 79% of respondents believe that climate change is a serious threat to future generations. What concerns you and what can the state do to address these threats? Tell us in the comments below.    iReport.com: What do you think about climate change?
